title_en: First to 'Induce' Nuclear Fission (But Misinterprets It)

summary.text_en: Enrico Fermi and his team in Rome were systematically bombarding every element with the newly-discovered 'neutron' (`chadwick_neutron_1932`). When they bombarded 'Uranium', they found new, intense radioactivity. They *incorrectly* interpreted this as the creation of 'Transuranic Elements' (elements heavier than Uranium, #92). **Fermi had, in fact, *induced* nuclear fission in 1934, but he *failed to recognize it*.** This 'misinterpretation' was accepted by the physics community for four years, and Fermi was even awarded the 1938 Nobel Prize for this 'discovery'.
key_points_en: First to 'induce' but *not recognize* nuclear fission
German chemist 'Ida Noddack' *correctly* hypothesized 'fission' in 1934, but was ignored
Fermi was (incorrectly) awarded the 1938 Nobel Prize for this

story.text_en:
Fermi's 'Rome group' were the pioneers of nuclear physics. After Chadwick (`chadwick_neutron_1932`) discovered the neutron, Fermi realized this 'neutral' particle was the 'perfect bullet' to shoot at nuclei. He started at hydrogen and worked his way up. When he hit the heaviest element, *Uranium*, he found radioactive products that *didn't* behave chemically like Uranium or any of its 'neighbors' (like lead). He concluded he must have created element 93 or 94.
The German chemist **Ida Noddack** (`noddack_fission_1934`) immediately published a paper arguing that Fermi's chemical analysis was incomplete, and *correctly* suggested it was 'conceivable that the nucleus *breaks up* into several large fragments' (i.e., *known* elements). This idea was too radical (it violated all known physics) and was *ignored* by everyone, including Fermi.
It wasn't until 1938 that Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann proved with chemistry that the 'new element' was, in fact, **Barium**â€”a *light* element about half the size of Uranium. Fermi (who was literally in Stockholm accepting his Nobel Prize for it) immediately realized Noddack had been right all along.

fun_facts.text_en: Fermi is one of the only scientists (if not the only one) to win a Nobel Prize for a *misinterpretation*. He later had to add a *footnote* to his published Nobel lecture acknowledging the subsequent discovery of fission.
Fermi's *other* discovery from 1934â€”'slow neutrons'â€”was completely correct and was the *actual* key to unlocking practical nuclear fission and building a reactor.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine shooting a 'BB pellet' (a neutron) at a 'watermelon' (a Uranium nucleus).
Fermi did this in 1934. He saw the watermelon 'split', but he *thought* he had just *stuck the BB pellet to it*, creating a 'Super-Watermelon' (a Transuranic element).
Ida Noddack shouted from the sidelines, 'Are you *sure* you didn't just *smash it* into *two cantaloupes*?' Fermi (and everyone else) ignored her.
Four years later, other scientists (Hahn & Strassmann) did the experiment again, looked closely at the pieces, and yelled, 'My God, it *is* a cantaloupe (Barium)!'
So, Fermi was the first person to *split* the atom, but he *didn't know he had done it*.

applications.text_en: Fermi's (mistaken) quest for 'transuranic elements' sparked an intense, 4-year research race across Europe that led directly to Hahn and Strassmann's discovery of the truth: fission.

impact.text_en: Fermi's 1934 experiment (and its misinterpretation) was the *critical first step* in the discovery of fission. It (unintentionally) started the chain of events that led Otto Hahn and Lise Meitner to *correctly* identify fission in 1938. Ida Noddack's ignored 1934 paper remains a classic case of correct intuition that lacked the necessary experimental or theoretical backing at the time.

influenced_by.contribution_en: James Chadwick (his discovery of the 'neutron' gave Fermi the 'perfect bullet' to bombard nuclei)
Joliot-Curies (their discovery of 'artificial radioactivity' was the immediate motivation for Fermi's neutron experiments)

influenced.contribution_en: Ida Noddack (her paper was the *first* to contradict Fermi and *hypothesize* fission)
Hahn, Meitner, & Strassmann (their work was a *direct attempt* to replicate and understand Fermi's 'transuranics', which led to them *disproving* it and finding fission)
(Himself) The Nuclear Reactor (once fission was confirmed, Fermi *immediately* used his *other* 1934 discovery ('slow neutrons') to build the first reactor)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Enrico Fermi was the first to 'knock on the door' of nuclear fission, but he thought he had found a different door.

quiz.question_en: When Enrico Fermi bombarded uranium with neutrons in 1934, what did he *incorrectly* think he had discovered?
quiz.explanation_en: Fermi assumed the neutron was *absorbed*, creating element 93. He did not conceive that the nucleus would *split* into smaller fragments (like Barium). Ida Noddack (`noddack_fission_1934`) hypothesized fission at the time, but was ignored.
